awd_titl_txt: Viscous Organic Liquids and Catalysis of Atmospheric Ice Nucleation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the NSF Division of Chemistry supports Prof. Sarah Brooks at Texas A&M University. Prof. Brooks and her students study the role of secondary organic aerosols SAO) in the nucleation of atmospheric ice particles. Recent measurements indicate that several current assumptions about the organic aerosol phase and the cloud-forming properties may be incorrect. First, the majority of SOA in the troposphere exist in a viscous, rather free-flowing liquid state. Second, the presence of viscous organic aerosols represents a previously unrecognized supply of particles capable of causing the freezing of ice crystals in clouds.  The data collected are used to assess the role of viscous phases and retarded water diffusion in atmospheric ice nucleation processes. The project also includes the training of graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students. During summers at Texas A&M, high school students attend the campus-wide TAMU Youth Adventure Program to participate in lecture and laboratory activities including, "The role of viscosity in the foods we love." 
	The team collects quantitative data on the phase, water diffusion, and ice nucleating ability of representative organic compounds and mixtures. The phases of sample aerosols are characterized by their temperature-dependent viscosities and the temperature at which they transition from liquid to glass using specialized spectroscopic techniques. In addition, the freezing temperatures of all samples are determined using our custom ice microscope technique. Taken together the data are used to evaluate whether a minimum glass transition temperature requirement exists for viscous aerosol to facilitate the freezing of droplets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ice rarely forms in the atmosphere, and never above -38 Celsius. Rather, for ice crystals to form on surface sites on solid atmosphere particles. In this project we set out to determine if and under what conditions particles which were liquid instead of solid could nucleate ice. We discovered that mixed organic sulfate solution drops can, indeed, act as ice nucleation particles. However, the time scales required for this to happen are hours or more, rather then seconds. This changes the way future ice nucleation measurements must be done, as the instrument most commonly used and most respective in this field cannot be operated with a residence time of any more than 10 seconds. Consequently, it and many techniques cannot be used to study ice nucleation accurate. Luckily, the simple cooling stage and digital camera we employ here can run for as many as 22 hours unattended, so it is well suited for long time scale, slow freezing experiments.

In addition, to ice nucleation, we characterize the viscosity of mixed organic/sulfate systems and also explored the role of pH is changing viscosity and ice nucleation temperatures. To date, the relationship between composition of mixed systems and viscosity is poorly understood, making modeling inaccurate.  Further, we speculate that the observed trend in glass transition temperatures  with mixture composition is caused by changes in hydrogen bonding level due to changing composition, which we further explored using Raman spectroscopy and molecular modeling of molecular structure using density function theory. Raman spectra provide evidence of the high degree of hydrogen bonding present in the mixed systems. Amongst the mixtures in this study, density function theory calculations on pairwise molecular groups confirm that the intermolecular interactions are strongest within the 3-methyltetrol-sulfate:3-methyltetrol-sulfate dimer (Figure 1).   These inferred and modeled intermolecular forces appear to give rise to the observed nonlinear changes in Tg with the composition of IEPOX-derived SOA constituents measured here. Molecular dynamics studies of systems larger than our studied binary complex clusters are needed to quantify the impact of these interactions on the glass transition temperatures of secondary organic (SOA)  aerosol systems and to assess the overall implications for atmospheric SOA. 

The broader impacts of this project feature a learning demonstration on "Viscosity of the Foods We Eat" which is very popular at Texas A&M Chemistry open houses, and the intensive training of  undergraduates in our research group.
